feed.title: Current watches, warnings, and advisories for United States land zones

entry.title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued August 18 at 1:32PM EDT until August 18 at 2:00PM EDT by NWS Baltimore MD/Washington DC
entry.summary:
At 132 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm was located over Harrisonburg, moving east at 10 mph.
HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and penny size hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Damaging winds will cause some trees and large branches to fall. This could injure those outdoors, as well as damage homes and vehicles. Roadways may become blocked by downed trees. Localized power outages are possible. Unsecured light objects may become projectiles.
Locations impacted include... Harrisonburg, Bridgewater, Massanutten, Dale Enterprise, Dayton, Mount Crawford, Penn Laird, Pleasant Valley, Lacey Spring, Linville, Keezletown, Mcgaheysville, Hinton, and Montevideo.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Rockingham, VA; City of Harrisonburg, VA

cap:parameter.value: A SEVERE THUNDERSTORM WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 200 PM EDT FOR SOUTH CENTRAL ROCKINGHAM AND THE CITY OF HARRISONBURG

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 18 at 1:29PM EDT by NWS State College PA
entry.summary:
At 129 PM EDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm over Mechanicsburg, moving northeast at 40 mph.
HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 50 mph and half inch hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects. Minor hail damage to vegetation is possible.
Locations impacted include... Harrisburg, Lower Allen, Hershey, Colonial Park, Progress, Mechanicsburg, Camp Hill, New Cumberland, Linglestown, Enola, Steelton, Lemoyne, Hummelstown, Paxtonia, Rutherford, Skyline View, Lawnton, Boiling Springs, Wormleysburg, and Bressler-Enhaut-Oberlin.

entry.title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued August 18 at 12:26PM CDT until August 18 at 1:00PM CDT by NWS Topeka KS
entry.summary:
SVRTOP
The National Weather Service in Topeka has issued a
* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for... Northern Dickinson County in central Kansas... Northwestern Geary County in east central Kansas... Riley County in northeastern Kansas... Southeastern Washington County in north central Kansas... Clay County in north central Kansas...
* Until 100 PM CDT.
* At 1226 PM CDT, severe thunderstorms were located along a line extending from 10 miles northwest of Randolph to near Clay Center to near Miltonvale, moving southeast at 40 mph.
HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and nickel size hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Expect damage to roofs, siding, and trees.
* Locations impacted include... Manhattan, Junction City, Clay Center, Ogden, Grandview Plaza, Wakefield, Riley, Clifton, Milford, Leonardville, Morganville, Randolph, Green, Manchester, Longford, Vining, Oak Hill, Talmage, Idana, and Milford Lake.
This includes Interstate 70 between mile markers 292 and 294, and between mile markers 296 and 305.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Clay, KS; Dickinson, KS; Geary, KS; Riley, KS; Washington, KS

entry.title: Flood Watch issued August 18 at 1:24PM EDT until August 19 at 2:00AM EDT by NWS Mount Holly NJ
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...Portions of northern Delaware, including the following area, New Castle, New Jersey, including the following areas, Camden, Gloucester, Hunterdon, Mercer, Middlesex, Morris, Northwestern Burlington, Salem, Somerset, Sussex, Warren and Western Monmouth, and Pennsylvania, including the following areas, Berks, Carbon, Delaware, Eastern Chester, Eastern Montgomery, Lehigh, Lower Bucks, Monroe, Northampton, Philadelphia, Upper Bucks, Western Chester and Western Montgomery.
* WHEN...Through late tonight.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Flooding may occur in poor drainage and urban areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Heavy rain and thunderstorms associated with an approaching cold front will produce widespread rainfall amounts of 1 to 3 inches with locally higher amounts of 4 inches or more possible. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued August 18 at 1:09PM EDT until August 18 at 3:30PM EDT by NWS Upton NY
entry.summary:
FFWOKX
The National Weather Service in Upton has extended the
* Flash Flood Warning for... Fairfield County in southern Connecticut... West Central New Haven County in southern Connecticut... Central Westchester County in southeastern New York...
* Until 330 PM EDT.
* At 109 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 2.5 and 5.5 inches of rain have fallen. The expected rainfall rate is 1 to 2 inches in 1 hour. Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is already occurring.
HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding.
SOURCE...Radar.
IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses.
* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Bridgeport, Stamford, Norwalk, Danbury, White Plains, Naugatuck, Port Chester, Southbury, New Canaan, Rye, Newtown, Fairfield, Greenwich, Trumbull, Harrison, Westport, Ridgefield, Darien, Monroe and Bethel.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Fairfield, CT; New Haven, CT; Westchester, NY

entry.summary:

* WHERE...East and south facing reefs of Kosrae.
* WHEN...Until 4 PM ChST this afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Dangerous swimming and surfing conditions and localized beach erosion.

entry.title: Flood Watch issued August 18 at 10:08AM MDT until August 18 at 10:00PM MDT by NWS Salt Lake City UT
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flash flooding caused by excessive rainfall is possible. Saturated antecedent conditions across southern Utah may make flash flooding more likely.
* WHERE...A portion of Utah, including the following areas, Central Mountains, Wasatch Plateau/Book Cliffs, Capitol Reef National Park and Vicinity, Glen Canyon Recreation Area/Lake Powell, South Central Utah, Southern Mountains, Upper Sevier River Valleys, Lower Washington County and Zion National Park.
* WHEN...Until 10 PM MDT this evening.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of slot canyons, normally dry washes, near recent burn scars including the Silver King Mine, Bear, Halfway Hill and Trail Mountain Burn Scars, and other flood prone locations.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Another disturbance lifting north into Utah combined with saturated antecedent conditions will bring an increased threat for flash flooding across the region. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Wasatch Plateau/Book Cliffs; Central Mountains; Lower Washington County; Zion National Park; Southern Mountains; Upper Sevier River Valleys; South Central Utah; Capitol Reef National Park and Vicinity; Glen Canyon Recreation Area/Lake Powell

entry.title: Flood Watch issued August 18 at 7:45AM AKDT until August 19 at 10:00AM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...Noatak Valley, South Slopes of the Western Brooks Range and Upper Kobuk Valleys. This includes the cities of Walker Lake, Noatak, Red Dog Mine, Ambler, Shungnak, And Kobuk.
* WHEN...Through Monday morning.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Area creeks and streams are running high and could flood with more heavy rain.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Additional precipitation through Monday is expected to be between 1 to 3 inches across the area, with the heaviest rainfall amounts expected along the southern slopes of the western Brooks Range. Expect rapid rises and flooding along smaller rivers and streams draining the western Brooks Range through the weekend. Heavy rainfall will also cause the Kobuk River to rise through next week, with the river potentially reaching flood stage by early next week.
- Http://www.weather.gov/aprfc
entry.cap:areaDesc: South Slopes of the Western Brooks Range; Noatak Valley; Upper Kobuk Valleys

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH MONDAY MORNING

entry.title: Flood Watch issued August 18 at 9:32AM EDT until August 18 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Baltimore MD/Washington DC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flash flooding caused by excessive rainfall.
* WHERE...Portions of DC, including the following , District of Columbia, Maryland, including the following areas, Anne Arundel, Carroll, Cecil, Central and Southeast Howard, Central and Southeast Montgomery, Northern Baltimore, Northwest Harford, Northwest Howard, Northwest Montgomery, Prince Georges, Southeast Harford and Southern Baltimore, and northern Virginia, including the following areas, Arlington/Falls Church/Alexandria, Eastern Loudoun and Fairfax.
* WHEN...From 2 PM this afternoon to 8 PM EDT this evening.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Flooding may occur in poor drainage and urban areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Widespread showers and thunderstorms are expected this afternoon into this evening with multiple rounds possible. Thunderstorms may be capable of producing intense rainfall rates of one to two inches per hour with locally higher amounts up to three inches. This may result in flash flooding of small streams and creeks as well as urban and poor drainage areas. - Please visit www.weather.gov/safety/flood for flood safety and preparedness information

entry.title: Coastal Flood Statement issued August 18 at 3:10AM HST until August 19 at 6:00PM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
entry.summary:
...MINOR COASTAL FLOODING DURING AFTERNOON HIGH TIDES THROUGH MONDAY...
.Higher-than-predicted water levels combined with near-peak monthly tides will lead to minor coastal flooding each afternoon through Monday. A south swell arriving tonight and peaking late Monday will increase the flooding potential along south facing shores Monday afternoon. Water levels will gradually lower Tuesday through the rest of the week.
* WHAT...Isolated minor coastal flooding.
* WHERE...Along shorelines and low-lying coastal areas of all islands.
* WHEN...Each afternoon through Monday during the peak daily high tide cycles.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of beaches that are normally dry, minor coastal erosion, and saltwater inundation.

entry.title: Coastal Flood Advisory issued August 18 at 4:37AM AKDT until August 18 at 6:00PM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
* LOCATION...Along the Kuskokwim Delta coast, especially the communities of Kongiganak, Kwigillingok, and Kipnuk.
* COASTAL FLOODING...Water levels will rise as high as 3 to 6 feet above normal highest tide. While water levels will drop during low tide, expect higher than usual water levels to return during high tide.
* TIMING...Through 6 PM Sunday, as a final round of strong winds impact the Kuskokwim Delta coast. The timing of highest water levels will depend on tide cycles at your location. The strongest winds are expected through this afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding of low lying areas along the coast. Strong winds, high surf, and wave run-up could move property along the shoreline. Coastal erosion is possible. Strong, sustained winds could slow the retreat of water during low tide.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...There is now increased confidence for the most significant higher water, waves and strong winds to occur around midday today. Winds and higher than normal water levels will slowly diminish by Sunday night.

cap:parameter.value: COASTAL FLOOD ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 PM AKDT THIS EVENING

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 18 at 8:37AM EDT by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
Santa Fe River At Three Rivers Estates affecting Suwannee, Columbia and Gilchrist Counties.
Additional information is available at https://water.weather.gov/wfo/JAX
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Santa Fe River at Three Rivers Estates.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 16.0 feet, Lowland flooding begins on SW Santa Fe Drive south of Santa Fe Road in Columbia County. At 16.3 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission begins enforcement of a no wake zone on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream of the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to the confluence with the Suwannee River and on the Ichetucknee River upstream to the US 27 bridge. At 17.0 feet, Water begins to enter backyards of residences on Santa Fe Road in Columbia County and on River Run Road in Suwannee County. At 18.0 feet, Water begins to flood River Run Road in Suwannee County. At 18.8 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission expands the no wake zone restriction further upstream on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream on the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to one-half mile upstream of the State Road 47 bridge. At 19.0 feet, Water begins to enter backyards of residences along the Ichetucknee River. At 19.8 feet, Waters begins to affect homes in the Hollingsworth Bluff area at State Route 47. At 20.0 feet, Access to homes on Santa Fe Road below SW Riverside Avenue becomes restricted in Columbia. Flooding begins on Santa Fe and Wilson Springs Road. At 21.0 feet, Homes are surrounded on River Run Road in Suwannee County. Structures flood along Santa Fe Road west of Idaho Parkway in Columbia County. At 22.0 feet, River Run Road at 29th loop floods in Suwannee County. Santa Fe Road in Columbia County is inaccessible. At 23.0 feet, Homes are inaccessible along River Run Road in Suwannee County west of 33rd Road.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:00 AM EDT Sunday the stage was 21.8 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall to 19.1 feet Sunday, August 25. - Flood stage is 17.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 18 at 3:04AM CDT by NWS Brownsville TX
entry.summary:
The combination of hot temperatures and elevated relative humidity values will result in moderate to major heat risk across Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley today. Heat index values are expected to range between 105 and 112 degrees this afternoon into early evening. Isolated areas may experience heat indices between 111 and 112 degrees for a short period of time.
If working outside today, be sure to drink plenty of water, wear loose-fitting and light-colored clothing, and take frequent breaks in air-conditioned locations. Be sure to check on elderly and infirm neighbors and relatives, provide shade and fresh water for outdoor pets and livestock, and check the backseat of your vehicle when transporting children.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Brooks; Inland Kenedy; Starr; Southern Hidalgo; Inland Willacy; Inland Cameron; Coastal Kenedy; Northern Hidalgo; Coastal Willacy; Coastal Cameron

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 17 at 1:23PM AKDT until August 19 at 6:00PM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
Winds from a coastal storm will cause water to backup on the Kuskokwim River and surrounding low lying areas.
* WHAT...Flooding caused by high winds backing up flow along the lower Kuskokwim River and Kuskokwim Delta is expected.
* WHERE...Along the Kuskokwim River, related tributaries and low lying areas including: Akiak, Bethel and several other smaller communities downstream to the Delta.
* WHEN...Until 600 PM AKDT Monday.
* IMPACTS...Residents reported flooding and rapid bank erosion during Friday and Saturday's high tide at Akiak, Napakiak, Kasigluk, and Tuntutuliak. At Napakiak, residents reported high water threatening community infrastructures, from Friday and Saturday's high tide, inundating most low spots in the village, including the the road to the dump. Water levels are reported to be higher than during breakup flooding this past May. Residents in Kasigluk reported water was encroaching on low lying residences, with water levels similar to those seen during this year's breakup. In Tuntutuliak, residents are reporting high water in the village over the past few days.
Based on tidal and storm surge forecasts, river levels are expected to be highest during Sunday's high tide, with water levels at Bethel, along Brown's Slough, approaching the flood stage of 8.5 feet by Sunday afternoon.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1240 PM AKDT, a strong storm system is expected to track just to the north of the Y-K Delta on Sunday, with strong southwest winds and associated storm surge blocking flow along the Kuskokwim River. High tide on Sunday will correspond closely to very high water levels along the lower Kuskokwim, causing inundation of homes and infrastructure, along with rapid bank erosion.
- Http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 PM AKDT MONDAY... ...REPLACES FLOOD ADVISORY

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 17 at 3:30PM CDT by NWS Duluth MN
entry.summary:
* WHAT...The Minnesota Pollution Control Agency has issued an Air Quality Alert for fine particles pollution. The Air Quality Index (AQI) is expected to reach the Orange or Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups category.
* WHERE...North central and northeastern Minnesota.
* WHEN...Until noon CDT Monday.
* IMPACTS...Sensitive groups, such as people with lung disease (including asthma), heart disease, and children and older adults, may experience health effects.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Heavy ground-level smoke is expected to move into northwest Minnesota Friday evening.. Northerly winds behind a strong low pressure system will pull smoke south across the northern half of Minnesota through Monday morning. Smoke will produce air quality in Orange (Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups) category intermittently from Friday evening through noon on Monday. The air quality may temporarily improve during the afternoon hours before degrading again overnight. Areas near Lake Superior may also experience smoke trapped in marine fog, similar to what occured earlier this week. Because of this air quality may be worse immediately surrounding Lake Superior compared to areas inland.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Koochiching; North St. Louis; Northern Cook/Northern Lake; North Itasca; Central St. Louis; Southern Lake/North Shore; Southern Cook/North Shore; North Cass; South Itasca; Northern Aitkin; Carlton/South St. Louis

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 17 at 3:37PM CDT by NWS Houston/Galveston TX
entry.summary:
AQAHGX
The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) has issued an Ozone Action Day for the Houston, Galveston, and Brazoria area for Sunday, August 18, 2024
Atmospheric conditions are expected to be favorable for producing high levels of ozone pollution in the Houston, Galveston, and surrounding areas on Sunday. You can help prevent ozone pollution by sharing a ride, walking, riding a bicycle, taking your lunch to work, avoiding drive through lanes, conserving energy and keeping your vehicle properly tuned.
For more information on ozone:
Ozone: The Facts www.tceq.texas.gov/airquality/monops/ozonefacts.html EPA AirNow: www.airnow.gov/?city=Houston&state=TX&country=USA Take Care of Texas: www.takecareoftexas.org/conservation-tips/keep-our-air-clean

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 16 at 12:16PM PDT by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
Oregon Department of Environmental Quality has issued an Air Quality Advisory...in effect until noon PDT Monday.
This air quality advisory covers Lake and northern Klamath counties due to wildfires burning in the region. The DEQ also expects intermittent smoke in eastern Douglas and Jackson County through this period due to smoke from surrounding fires.
The wildfire smoke combined with forecast conditions will cause air quality levels to fluctuate and could be at unhealthy levels.
Smoke levels can change rapidly depending on the weather and planned burn operations. Smoke can irritate the eyes and lungs and worsen some medical conditions. People most at risk include infants and young children, people with heart or lung disease, older adults and pregnant people.
People can take the following precautions to protect their health:
- Follow local burn restrictions to prevent deteriorating air quality. - Avoid strenuous outdoor activity during periods of poor air quality. - People with heart or lung problems and young children are especially vulnerable. These people should stay indoors while smoke levels are high. - Use certified High Efficiency Particulate Air (HEPA) filters in indoor heating, ventilation, cooling and air purification systems. - Avoid using wood-burning stoves and other sources of indoor smoke if possible.
For additional information...please visit the web site at https://oregonsmoke.org

cap:parameter.value: AIR QUALITY ALERT IN EFFECT UNTIL NOON PDT MONDAY

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 16 at 10:53AM PDT by NWS Pendleton OR

A Smoke Air Quality Advisory has been issued. Wildfires burning in the region combined with forecasted conditions will cause air quality to reach unhealthy levels.
Pollutants in smoke can cause burning eyes...runny nose...aggravate heart and lung diseases...and aggravate other serious health problems. Limit outdoor activities and keep children indoors if it is smoky. Please follow medical advice if you have a heart or lung condition.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 15 at 3:08PM CDT by NWS Grand Forks ND
entry.summary:
* WHAT...The Minnesota Pollution Control Agency has issued an Air Quality Alert for fine particles pollution. The Air Quality Index (AQI) is expected to reach the Red or Unhealthy category.
* WHERE...Northwest Minnesota.
* WHEN...From 3 PM CDT Friday to 6 PM CDT Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Some members of the general public may experience health effects. Sensitive groups, such as people with lung disease (including asthma), heart disease, and children and older adults, may experience health effects.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Heavy ground-level smoke is expected to move into northwest Minnesota on Friday afternoon. Northerly winds behind a strong low pressure system will pull smoke south across the Red River valley. Smoke will reach the border around 3 pm and arrive at the Fargo/Moorhead area around 6 pm Friday. Northerly winds will persist for several days and additional smoke is expected to move into northern Minnesota Saturday afternoon. The alert area may need to be expanded to account for additional areas that might be impacted by heavy smoke. Smoke will initially produce air quality in the Red (Unhealthy) AQI category Friday afternoon but levels may improve to the Orange (Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups) category on Saturday. Smoke will linger until at least Sunday, as light northerly winds are expected to continue until Monday.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 15 at 12:29PM EDT until August 20 at 11:00AM EDT by NWS Wilmington NC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding from the Intracoastal Waterway
* WHERE...A portion of northeast South Carolina, including the following county, Horry.
* WHEN...Until 1100 AM EDT Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...At 17 feet...flooding of about three dozen ground level structures on Rosewood Drive, Star Creek Circle, and Recreation Road worsens and about 24 more ground level structures begin to flood. Flooding expands on Rosewood Drive, River Road, Ed Smith Avenue, Creekside Drive, Mill Creek Road, Smith Boulevard, Folly Lane, John Henry Lane, Star Creek Circle, West Oak Circle and Roberta Lane with residences isolated. Zeddie Lane, Renata Lane, and Earls Road begin to flood. Lowest yards along Shem Creek Circle begin to flood.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1226 PM EDT, The Waterway at Socastee was at about 15.2 feet and is forecast to rise to a peak as high as 17 feet Monday into Tuesday. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Socastee. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
